awd_titl_txt: Synthesizing and Harnessing Ultracold Single Molecules for Quantum Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
Atoms and molecules are the building blocks of everyday matter, and scientists are learning to control these building blocks with ever more precision. In one noteworthy example, quantum control of atoms was used to build atomic clocks that enable the Global Positioning System (GPS).  More recently, scientists discovered that atoms and molecules can be harnessed to build a quantum simulator, a resource for studying complex quantum phenomena.  This is important because quantum simulators may lead to advances in chemistry, medicine, computation, and several other scientific fields that contribute to the national health and economy.  However, a reliable way to build useful quantum simulators is not yet known. This project aims to pioneer methods to prepare and control individual molecules for use in a quantum simulator. If these basic steps are successful, then larger quantum simulators can be built using these principles.   This project will also train graduate students and undergraduate students to use molecular physics and quantum control techniques, and this will prepare them to participate in the high technology work force.

This project aims to develop a source of trapped ultracold ground-state molecules with single particle manipulation and detection capability, which are crucial to future quantum applications. To develop tools to build such diatomic molecules atom-by-atom, many widely used Atomic Molecular and Optical (AMO) physics techniques need to be further updated and expanded in order to access a much broader array of atoms and molecules. This includes the ability to trap single atoms by fast alternating trapping and cooling beams to eliminate light shifts, Raman sideband cooling of single atoms outside the Lamb-Dicke regime, and coherent all-optical atom-to-molecule conversion without large spontaneous emission. Many new tools will be explored, including atomic species-dependent optical tweezers for transportation without motional excitation. Combining such exquisite control of individual atoms with a tightly focused spectroscopy laser beam will enable the first realization of single molecule spectroscopy in the gas phase.  Such a novel source of two atoms would also provide a new paradigm of collisional study in which the exact number of participating collision partners are prepared. Furthermore, one could use the rich manifold of internal states of molecules as synthetic dimensions, strong electric dipolar interactions, and flexible geometric arrangement of the molecules in order to study novel phases of matter such as many-body localization and a quantum dipolar spin liquid.

por.por_cntn:
This project demonstrated a series of “molecular assembly” steps and techniques to gain total quantum state control of an individual molecule trapped in an optical tweezer, which is formed by a tightly focused laser beam. Starting with individual atoms of two different atomic species (one sodium and one cesium) trapped in separate optical tweezers, the atoms are cooled to their lowest motional state of the confining potential. While prior techniques have already demonstrated cooling of single atoms to their lowest motional state, we further generalized it to enable cooling of single atoms where the characteristic wavefunction spread of the atoms is larger than the wavelength of light used to address the atoms. Specifically, we devised a laser pulse sequence to cool the light mass element sodium by removing several motional quanta at a time. Next, we demonstrated steering atoms from two separate optical tweezers to the same location and trap them by a single beam while keeping them in the lowest motional state by adjusting the tweezer laser powers and positions to always have a global minimum from the perspective of each atom. From there, we studied their interaction and probed the underlying potentials. We extracted Na-Cs scattering lengths and identified several magnetic scattering resonances in the range of 800-900 Gauss. We then utilized such a resonance to bind the atoms into weakly bound molecules. Doing so, we transfer the quantum control of the atoms to the resulting molecules. The final step in this molecular assembly process is to coherently transfer the molecules into the rovibrational ground state. We performed Na-Cs molecular spectroscopy to identify a favorable intermediate state to bridge the large energy gap and remove the binding energy without heating up the molecules. We showed coherent Rabi oscillation between NaCs in the weakly bound and the rovibrational ground state. Through this process, a molecule is tamed in all its degrees of freedom and is ready to serve as building blocks for quantum simulations. Our approach to gain single molecules with quantum control has generated a lot of interest in the AMO community as well as in the physical chemistry community. Several labs worldwide have started a similar pursuit of single molecules. Some of our techniques are also being adopted for works on atom optical tweezer arrays with multiple species. The project also support student trainings: Two graduate students completed their PhDs under the support of the grant and they continue to pursue a career in science and engineering. Several undergraduate students and 1 high school student also gained research experience through this project. The research results supported under this grant were published in 5 journal articles (2 in Phys. Rev. Lett, 2 in Phys. Rev. X, and 1 in Phys. Rev. Research)
